Acronyms for particular cryptocurrencies — for instance, USDC for U.S. digital coin — should still be fully capitalized. bitcoin The first cryptocurrency to attain significant popularity. It was designed by an unknown person or group using the pseudonym Satoshi Nakamoto and launched in 2009. As of early 2024, bitcoin was the most popular cryptocurrency system available. Lowercase all references to bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies, consistent with the style for conventional currency. As with other cryptocurrencies, bitcoins do not exist as physical bills or coins. Rather, they exist as blocks of data that are digitally signed each time they travel from one owner to the next. Bitcoin and other digital currencies are subject to wild price swings because unlike dollars, euros and other traditional currencies, cryptocurrencies are not backed by governments, central banks or, for the most part, physical assets. blockchain A distributed digital ledger of cryptocurrency transactions that is maintained across a worldwide network. In general, different cryptocurrencies use different blockchains, although some new cryptocurrencies have been established on existing blockchains. Blockchain records are stored in a "peer-to-peer" network that updates continually so that copies of these records are stored across computers around the world. Blockchain records are secured through cryptography. Participants have their own private keys that act as personal digital signatures for accessing their funds. Cryptocurrency transactions are digitally signed each time cryptocurrency changes hands. miners, validators Blockchains are constructed by people known as miners or validators , who verify cryptocurrency transactions so that no one can spend the same token twice. Miners use their computing power to compete to solve a math puzzle. The first to solve the puzzle gets to add the verified transaction to the blockchain. This method is used for the bitcoin and dogecoin blockchains. Validators use a proof of stake method, where they pledge or "stake" a portion of their holdings of a particular cryptocurrency and are chosen to attest to the validity of a transaction. Ethereum switched to proof of stake in 2022. Miners and validators receive cryptocurrency as a reward. Web3 A catchall term for the prospect of a new stage of the internet driven by the cryptocurrency-related technology blockchain. nonfungible token, NFT Artificially scarce digital objects created by using blockchain technology to mint "unique" versions of digital artwork, sports memorabilia, famous photographs and anything else that can be digitized. NFT is acceptable on first reference, but use the full term high in the story and explain what it means. stablecoin A type of cryptocurrency whose value is pegged to another asset, such as a fiat currency or gold, to maintain a stable price and designed to provide an alternative to the volatility of some of the popular cryptocurrencies. Tether is the most popular and largest stablecoin by market value. cyber- In general, internet, digital or a similar term is preferred, as in internet shopping or online security . When necessary to use, follow the general rule for prefixes, which calls for no hyphen in most cases. For example: cyberattack, cyberbullying, cybersecurity . But Cyber Monday, cyber liability insurance . cyberattack A computer operation carried out over a device or network that causes physical damage or significant disruption. The term is routinely overused — mostly as regards cyberespionage, used inaccurately sometimes to describe intrusions or breaches that do not cause harm or disruption — at least not immediately. darknet A part of the internet hosted within an encrypted network and accessible only through specialized anonymity-providing tools, most notably the Tor Browser. Examples of darknets include the Tor network, I2P and Freenet . Do not confuse darknets , which are generally associated with illegal or antisocial activity, and the much broader deep web . deepfake (n., adj.) A manipulated video or other digital representation produced by sophisticated machine learning techniques that yield seemingly realistic, but fabricated, images and sounds. Deepfake video can, for instance, make it appear that people said or did things they did not actually say or do. Deepfake or deepfake video is acceptable, but must be explained on first reference. See misinformation, fact checks, fake news . deep web A general term for portions of the internet that are not indexed by standard search engines such as Google and Bing, although they can be accessed by direct links. The deep web hosts a vast amount of legal but nonpublic activity, including private corporate websites known as intranets , secured databases, financial and medical accounts, legal files, and other data protected by paywalls or requiring secure logins. The darknet is a subset of the deep web . device memory, device storage The memory of a computer, phone or other digital device holds data needed for current operations; it is typically wiped clean when the device shuts down. Device storage , by contrast, holds data indefinitely unless deliberately erased. Memory and storage are both measured in bytes . Storage can take the form of a traditional magnetic hard-disk drive or a solid-state drive, which keeps data on semiconductor chips and is widely used in smartphones and other portable electronics. digital advertising, internet advertising, online advertising Advertising delivered digitally, such as on a website or an app, often targeted to a person's location, interests and other preferences. Ad revenue finances many free tech services, such as Facebook and Google, but it has also drawn scrutiny over data collection and privacy. See internet privacy . Types of digital advertising include: search advertising Ads, usually in text, that appear alongside search results, targeted to the specific keywords typed by the user. They can also appear on third-party websites such as news sites. display advertising A video or image ad displayed on a website or app. It can be targeted based on keywords in an article or the specific user's personal profile. video advertising Can include traditional television commercials shown over the internet. It can appear before or during breaks in streaming video or in a pop-up window when visiting a website. affiliate advertising An advertising model in which a company pays a third party for bringing traffic or leads to its service or products. For example, if a third-party website posts a link to Amazon, it could receive commissions for products bought through that link. With most types of digital advertising, an advertiser can specify the intended audience based on location, demographics, hobbies, interests and other factors. With some services, including Google and Facebook, a business can share a list of its existing customers, based on unique identifiers such as email addresses, and have the service find other customers with similar demographics, behavior and other attributes. Facebook calls this look-alike audience . Google calls it similar audience . Other types of targeting include: retargeting A method of targeting an audience based on previous behavior. For example, if someone clicks on an ad or visits a shopping site but does not buy, an ad for that same product could appear later when visiting another website or app. microtargeting The practice of targeting ads to even smaller groups of people, sometimes even individuals, by specifying a collection of user attributes to match. For example, advertisers can seek users who live in specific ZIP codes, have kids, like football, watch "Saturday Night Live" and have attended a specific school. The more specific the requirements, the narrower the audience. Additional advertising terms: pay per click A form of paid advertising in which an advertiser pays the service for every click made by visitors. Hyphenate as a modifier: pay-per-click advertising . pay per impression A form of paid advertising in which an advertiser pays the service every time the ad is shown, regardless of whether the user clicks on the ad. Hyphenate as a modifier: pay-per-impression advertising . click-through rate The number of clicks based on a set number of impressions. Many services now let advertisers specify how much they are willing to pay per impression or click. The service would then display the highest bidder for a particular set of keywords or other targeting attributes. This approach is often referred to as an auction, or real-time bidding . digital assistant, virtual assistant, voice assistant Artificial intelligence service offered via phones or home devices that responds to spoken questions or commands. Some systems allow questions or commands to be typed. Major voice assistants include Alexa from Amazon, Siri from Apple, Google Assistant from Google, Bixby from Samsung and Cortana from Microsoft. Although many of these assistants have traditionally female names, do not refer to them using gendered pronouns except in direct quotations. These services have experienced some problems with privacy. Some users have reported cases in which a device mistakenly identified command words and then recorded and sent background conversations online. Audio recordings of voice commands are typically kept online and can be sought in investigations and lawsuits. Major companies offer users the ability to review and delete recordings. Some tech companies also allow their employees or contractors to review voice interaction for quality control, although users can often opt out of such reviews. digital wallet, mobile wallet A phone app used to store credit cards, gift cards, loyalty cards, tickets and other transactional items. Such a wallet can include cards used for mobile payments and other digital items such as vaccination records. The terms digital wallets or mobile wallets are acceptable, but depending on the audience, the wallet terminology may require explanation on first use. Avoid e-wallet . See mobile payment . digitize, digitalize The term digitize generally has a narrow meaning and refers to a conversion of everyday analog information – sights, sounds, etc. –  to digital form: to digitize a document . Digitalize can have a broader meaning that refers to a transformation by embracing digital technologies: to digitalize an industry . direct message A private message sent via an online service. DM is acceptable on second reference. Can also be used as a verb: to direct-message or DM someone. disk, disc Use disk for magnetic computer media ( diskette, floppy disk, hard disk ) and medical references, such as a slipped disk . Use the disc spelling for optical media (a Blu-ray Disc, CD, DVD ) and for disc brake . DNS Abbreviation for the Domain Name System , an international network of directories that keep track of internet names and addresses. Spell out on first reference. See domain name . domain name The address used to locate a website or reach an email system. In email addresses, it is the portion to the right of the @ sign. It includes a suffix that often defines the type of entity, such as .com (for commerce), .gov (for U.S. government), .fr (for France) and .bank (for financial institutions). There are also domains that use non-Latin characters such as those in Arabic and Japanese. Some domain suffixes are restricted to specific types of institutions such as banks, but institutions aren't required to use any particular suffix. Though domain names are less prominent these days as more people reach websites using search engines and apps, they are still important for email addresses, billboards and other nondigital advertising. When writing about the suffix, use .com, .org , etc. Reserve dot-com for historical references to online businesses in the early days of the web and to the 2000 financial crash that followed the dot-com bubble . See DNS ; dot-com . dot-com An older and informal description of companies that do business mainly on the internet. Usually reserved for internet companies that thrived in the years 1995-2000, a period often known as the dot-com era . When referring to the domain name itself, use .com . See domain name . DVD Acceptable in all references for digital video disc , similar to CD-ROMs , but able to hold more music, video or data. DVR Acceptable in all references for digital video recorder , a feature of streaming television services that can search out and automatically record shows and movies as they are aired by cable or satellite channels. The term originally referred to stand-alone devices such as TiVo that once performed this function. emoji (s. and pl.) A symbol, such as a cartoon face, hand gesture, animal or other object, that might be used instead of a word or as an illustration in text messages or on social media. For guidance on quoting social media posts with emoji, see quotations in the news . emoticon A typographical cartoon or symbol generally used to indicate mood or appearance, as :-) and sometimes looked at sideways. Also known as smileys . Facebook (company) Former name of the company Meta Platforms which owns the world's most popular social network, Facebook. The company adopted the name Meta Platforms in October 2021 to signal its intention of building the metaverse , a proposed immersive digital environment that could in theory supplant the internet. See Meta Platforms ; Facebook (social platform) ; Family of Apps ; metaverse . Facebook (social platform) The world's most popular social network, with about 3.07 billion monthly active users as of Dec. 31, 2023. It is owned by Meta Platforms , the company formerly known as Facebook . Facebook, the social platform, connects billions of users and tracks their activity closely, allowing it to build individual profiles it can use for selling targeted advertising. That business has been hugely profitable. But Facebook's technology for keeping users as engaged as possible has also drawn significant criticism from those who say it foments hate speech, genocide and extremism; invades users' privacy; and promotes dangerous misinformation. Whistleblower and former Facebook data scientist Frances Haugen testified before Congress in October 2021 that the company knew that its platforms (Facebook as well as Instagram) spread misinformation and content that harms children but refused to make changes that could hurt its profit. Facebook is also under scrutiny for alleged anticompetitive practices and has been sued by the Federal Trade Commission and several states on those grounds. It faces lawsuits by dozens of states for harming young people's mental health. See Meta Platforms . Family of Apps Meta Platforms' name for its social apps and services. It includes the Facebook social network, Messenger , Instagram and WhatsApp . See Meta Platforms ; Facebook (social platform) . fintech Short for financial technology , fintech loosely refers to products and services designed to let consumers and businesses conduct banking and other financial services digitally. It can include the technology behind mobile and online banking, money transfers among friends and tools for finding cheaper loans. Fintech can involve both consumer-facing products and back-end services and can come from both startups and established financial institutions. Fintech can be used on first reference but should be defined in the story if it isn't clear from context. Use lowercase except at the start of sentences or in the formal name of a company. firewall A device or software designed to stop malicious or unauthorized internet traffic from reaching a computer or local data network. Many firewalls also inspect outgoing traffic. 5G, 4G, 3G Types of mobile network technology. 5G — a shorthand term for fifth generation wireless networks — refers to a faster alternative to the 4G mobile networks that have been in widespread U.S. service since the mid-2010s. In addition to faster speeds, 5G networks promise reduced signal lag, which can improve performance for some services. Only newer phones updated for 5G will work with these new networks. Some providers are also using 5G for fixed mobile networks that can deliver broadband speeds to homes and businesses. 3G refers to 4G's slower predecessor. Major 3G networks in the U.S. largely shut down in 2022, although in some other countries they are scheduled to remain operational for several years. 3G, 4G and 5G are acceptable on first reference, but should be explained in stories as cellular or mobile networks . Acceptable descriptions of 5G include faster, latest or next-generation network . Avoid the term fifth generation . No certification is required for a phone company to use any of these terms in marketing materials; be wary of possible deception. Some companies have used the 5G label for services that aren't technically 5G . Do not confuse these terms with Wi-Fi , which describes short-range wireless networks that do not use cellular technology. See Wi-Fi . 4K The term typically refers to video with 2,160 lines of vertical resolution, producing sharper images than high-definition video. The name derives from a version that offers 4,096 lines of horizontal resolution, though the term now usually refers to a version with just 3,840 horizontal lines, also known as ultrahigh definition , or UHD . Many TVs now come with 4K capabilities even though not all movies and shows are available in 4K. 4K is considered a successor to high-definition video . friend, follow, like Acceptable in a social media context as both nouns and verbs. Actions by which users connect to other users on social networks and engage with their content. GDPR The European Union's General Data Protection Regulation , a set of strict data privacy rules for citizens of the 27 nation EU that took effect in 2018. GDPR has been widely described as the world's strongest privacy law and gives people in the EU more control over their personal data. GDPR is acceptable on second reference, but use sparingly. Consider phrasing such as the rules or the privacy rules on later references. geolocation, geotagging The act of adding geographical metadata to pieces of media, social media updates or other digital content. Also, the use of a user's physical location to determine access to certain information. The metadata itself is an item's geolocation or geotag . A geotagged tweet, post, photo or video would contain information about the latitude and longitude of the location where the photo was taken, or possibly the name of the city and/or country, or of a landmark or establishment where the user has chosen to check in. GIF Acronym for Graphics Interchange Format , a compression format for images. In common usage, the term refers to images produced in this format for online use, frequently in the context of humorous social media posts. The pronunciation of GIF is disputed, with different camps preferring either a soft-g or hard-g initial consonant. The English language has no settled pronunciation rules for words beginning with the letters "gi," suggesting that this question is unlikely to be resolved to anyone's satisfaction. GIF is acceptable in copy but should be explained in the story. Use lowercase in a file name. For guidance on quoting social media posts with GIFs , see quotations in the news . Google Internet company that runs a dominant search engine and a major digital advertising network. Parent company is Alphabet. Google owns other digital products and services such as the Android operating system for mobile devices, the Chrome web browser, the Gmail email service, the YouTube video service, Pixel smartphones and smart home products branded Nest . Alphabet also owns several former Google-run businesses, including an investment division, a health services startup and the self-driving car company Waymo . Like many other Big Tech companies, Google is investing heavily in artificial intelligence . See the Artificial Intelligence chapter; Big Tech ; internet privacy . Google Cloud, Google Docs, Google Drive, Google Sheets But Google's cloud services . GPS Acceptable in all references to Global Positioning System . If a descriptive word is used following, use it in lowercase: the GPS satellite . hacker, hacktivism, hacktivist The term hacker is commonly used for someone who penetrates computer systems without authorization. The term originally referred to anyone with expertise in programming or hardware who tinkers with technology to understand its workings and explore new uses. Hacktivism consists of using computer skills as a form of protest or to try to effect change, typically in service of a cause or to expose perceived injustice. It can include defacing websites, launching denial-of-service attacks or hacking into networks and publicly leaking information. Explain the term if writing for a general audience. Hacktivists are individuals with computer skills primarily driven by political or social motives rather than personal gain. They use their skills to advance a cause or expose perceived injustice. Explain the term if writing for a general audience. While early hacktivists claimed and generally had altruistic goals, shadowy actors serving the interests of nation-states and other political forces have in more recent years conducted operations under the banner of "hacktivism" that warp its definition. handle A self-selected, public-facing username on a social network. May be used interchangeably with username . hashtag A term starting with a number or hash sign (#) in a social network post. It conveys the subject of the post so that it can be easily found by users interested in that subject. For example, the hashtag #UNGA is commonly used for the annual meeting of the U.N. General Assembly. A hashtag needs to be an uninterrupted string of characters, with no spaces. The use of hashtags has evolved to also reflect a post's tone. For example, a user may add #sarcasm or #feelingstupid to help describe the nature of a post. When posting, take note that the use of a hashtag associated with a movement or cause could be interpreted as a sign of support. AP journalists should avoid this, unless the hashtag itself is the subject of the post. In stories, write the hashtag as it would appear on a social network: The #Jan25 hashtag was credited with spreading support for the Egyptian uprising in its early days. HDMI Acceptable on all references for High-Definition Multimedia Interface , a system of cables and connectors used to transmit and receive high-definition video. Commonly used to connect DVD players, digital video recorders and other video devices to television sets and computers. HDR Abbreviation for high dynamic range , a feature found in both modern displays and photography. HDR is acceptable on first reference, but should be explained in the story. In video playback: A display feature that permits brighter whites and darker blacks. HDR can refer to television sets, tablets and other displays with the capability. Video adapted for HDR uses formats such as HDR10 and Dolby Vision . HDR displays and video also typically produce a wider range of colors, although that is technically not part of HDR . In photography: A camera feature that automatically blends multiple shots of the same subject taken at different exposures in order to prevent bright areas from being too bright and dark areas from being too dark. Some smartphones now have the feature on by default. hertz This term, the same in singular or plural, has been adopted as the international unit of frequency equal to one cycle per second. In contexts where it would not be understood by most readers, it should be followed by a parenthetical explanation: 15,400 hertz (cycles per second) . Do not abbreviate. high definition (n.) high-definition (adj.) The term refers to video with at least 720 lines of vertical resolution. HD is acceptable on second reference. HDTV is acceptable on second reference for a high-definition television set. A U.S. DVD or analog TV broadcast has 480 lines of vertical resolution — neither is HD. Many newer TVs have even sharper resolution, with 2,160 lines of vertical resolution, also known as 4K , although not all movies and shows are available in 4K . homepage The "front" page of a website. hot spot Two words. Used to describe an area where computers can connect wirelessly, a troubled global locale, or an area of intense heat in general. HTML Acceptable on all references for Hypertext Markup Language . In stories, describe as the web programming language known as HTML . HTTP, HTTPS Acceptable on all references for Hypertext Transfer Protocol . The term has long identified the start of web addresses such as http://apnews.com, although modern browsers no longer display or require entry of the "http://" part. It has also been largely supplanted by HTTPS , a secure version of HTTP used to create URLs to websites whose traffic cannot be easily eavesdropped on. IM Acceptable on second reference for instant message . Sometimes used as a verb: IM'ing, IM'd . An instant message is similar but not identical to a direct message ; both offer person-to-person communication, but instant messages are usually associated with apps such as Apple's iMessage whose primary purpose is to connect individuals or small groups. Direct messages are generally associated with broader communication platforms such as Facebook. Instagram Photo- and video-sharing service owned by Meta Platforms . internet A decentralized worldwide network of computers and other devices that undergirds global communications. An outgrowth of a 1960s Pentagon project, the internet blossomed as computers grew cheaper and smaller while the World Wide Web made communication simpler and more visual. The web , like email , is a service of the internet . The terms are not synonymous and should not be used interchangeably. See the Social Media Reporting chapter; misinformation, fact checks, fake news . Internet of Things General term used to describe devices, appliances, sensors and other gadgets with internet connections. This somewhat obscure term should be avoided in stories for general readers. Instead, use internet-connected or smart , such as internet-connected thermostat or smart light bulb . See smart devices . internet privacy A major issue for Big Tech companies and their users, particularly as governments begin cracking down on how corporations can use the personal information their users provide as part of their online activities. Companies such as Google and Facebook have long vacuumed up the personal information users share online — often unknowingly — in order to better target digital ads or predict buying behavior. Awareness of these tactics rose substantially in 2018 when Facebook acknowledged that a political consulting firm, Cambridge Analytica, had mined data on millions of users through a Facebook app that purported to be a psychological research tool. Technologies such as browser cookies and mobile device IDs can follow individual users as they move across websites and use different apps. Data collected online and in the physical world via personal devices ranging from fitness trackers to smart home appliances can include users' physical locations, recreational pursuits, home schedules, shopping and dietary habits, favorite sports teams and celebrities, vacation destinations, publications read, and television shows watched. Companies can also infer race or political views based on the types of sites visited online. Proponents of data collection and targeted advertising say the practice makes ads more relevant to users and cheaper for advertisers. But governments, particularly in the European Union and U.S. states such as California, have since passed measures that limit how companies collect and share such data. For instance, websites now commonly ask users for permission before saving their personal information in data cookies, a practice that once occurred behind the scenes. See opt in, opt out . Companies often say they don't sell data to third parties, a misleading statement that obscures the fact that they often make it available to advertising partners for free when users click their ads. Companies also frequently do in-house targeting on behalf of customers, allowing them to make money off user data without any need to sell it. See digital advertising, internet advertising, online advertising . internet privacy laws The United States has a patchwork of federal and state laws that cover different segments of data privacy, like health data, financial information or protections for children. But there's no single, comprehensive federal law regulating how companies collect, store or share consumer data. Data protections in the United States are notably different than in the European Union, which has a comprehensive data privacy law — the General Data Protection Regulation, a set of strict data privacy rules for citizens of the EU that took effect in 2018. See GDPR . internet security As many aspects of daily life and business have moved online, so have thieves, vandals and spies. Keeping organizations, individuals and their data protected online is an increasingly challenging task that has acquired a specialized vocabulary. Some terms: encryption The mathematical scrambling of messages in order to shield them from unauthorized viewing or modification. Such encrypted messages can typically be read only by the sender and the intended recipient, although in the case of commercial messaging systems, the service provider can often also decrypt and access messages and data such as files, photos or video. end-to-end encryption A way of encrypting messages such that only the sender and recipient can read them. The messaging service does not have the ability to read or modify such messages. That also means it cannot respond to requests from law enforcement; in response, government agencies have been pushing services to create backdoors just for them, though security experts warn that any backdoor for governments could also be exploited by criminals and other parties. Services that offer end-to-end encryption include Signal , Apple's iMessage and Meta Platforms' WhatsApp and Messenger . No encryption method is foolproof, and advances in computing power and cryptographic methods can often unlock messages encrypted by older technologies. Hackers can also sometimes exploit undiscovered bugs in encryption software to illicitly read supposedly secure messages or files. Attackers often break into seemingly secure systems by exploiting vulnerabilities – software or hardware flaws that can be used to bypass security protections. A zero-day vulnerability is such a flaw that has gone undetected by the system's creators and security reviews; explain this term when used in stories for general audiences. malware A general term for software that takes harmful or surreptitious actions, usually to steal data or money, access secure systems, or disrupt organizations. Malware can spread via phishing , "poisoned" websites that resemble familiar destinations, apps, or by exploiting vulnerabilities in computer systems. phishing Exploits the trust of users to attack computer systems or to commit fraud by stealing personal information such as credit card numbers, Social Security numbers, user IDs and passwords. The technique typically involves doctored emails often apparently sent by friends, family or co-workers that contain attachments or links to sites that infect a user's computer with malware. spyware Designed to ransack personal information, track the online activity of individuals, and sometimes to conduct surveillance via device microphones and cameras. ransomware Essentially holds a target computer or computer system hostage by encrypting its files and demanding payment, often via bitcoin. Ransomware can target individuals, businesses and governments alike. denial-of-service attack Entails targeting an internet site with enormous volumes of spurious data traffic. When successful, such attacks can knock a site or service offline until their operators find a way to divert the traffic elsewhere. Sometimes abbreviated DoS , although this shorthand is best avoided. A distributed denial-of-service attack , sometimes abbreviated DDoS , employs a network of distributed computers to direct junk traffic at the target site. botnet A collection of computers infected with malware that can be centrally controlled to conduct cyberattacks. Botnets have been used to carry out denial-of-service attacks, spread malware , send spam and steal data. Botnets can include a variety of devices, from desktop PCs to servers to household smart devices such as internet-connected video cameras. See cyberattack . internet service provider ISP is acceptable on second reference. intranet A private network inside a company or organization intended for internal use. IP address Short for Internet Protocol address , a numeric address given to a computer connected to the internet. Most users never see IP addresses ; instead they type in domain names such as apnews.com as stand-ins for the numeric address. Background domain name servers translate from IP addresses to text and back. IP addresses can sometimes be used to identify the location of a computer, the company or organization it belongs to, and where it was registered. Avoid the term in most stories. If necessary, IP address is acceptable on first reference with explanation, such as: Hackers targeted the site's IP address, a numeric designation that identifies its location on the internet. See domain name . IT Abbreviation for information technology . For general audiences, use IT only on second reference. For more technically oriented audiences, IT is acceptable on all references. JPEG, JPG Acceptable in all uses for the term Joint Photographic Experts Group , a common image format used on the World Wide Web. kilohertz Equals 1,000 hertz (1,000 cycles per second). Spell out on first reference. Abbreviate kHz . LED Short for light-emitting diode , a semiconductor device that lights up when electric current is applied. Unlike traditional light bulbs, LEDs produce light in one direction and are generally much more energy-efficient. LED is acceptable on first reference. lidar (n., adj.) Short for light detection and ranging , lidar is a sensing method that uses pulses of laser light to determine the presence, shape and distance of objects, often in great detail. Many autonomous vehicles – excepting those made by Tesla – use lidar for guidance; the technology also has many research applications, particularly in generating precise three-dimensional renderings of Earth's surface. It can detect objects in darkness and at times in bad weather. The term is acceptable on first reference with explanation. As an adjective: lidar sensors or lidar lasers . Line Messaging service operated by Tokyo-based Line , which is owned largely by SoftBank and South Korean tech company Naver . LinkedIn A social media network owned by Microsoft that's used mainly for professional networking. livestream, livestreaming login, logon, logoff (n.) But use as two words in verb form: I log in to my computer. mashup A blending of two or more pieces of content, such as photos or video. For example, a video that combines audio from a song with footage from movies and overlays it with bits of text. megahertz A measure of radio frequency or the speed of a computer processor, equal to a million hertz, or cycles per second. Spell out on first reference. Abbreviate MHz . metadata Behind-the-scenes data that provides important information about a piece of content. Examples include information about when or where information was created, by whom and in what format. If metadata is mentioned in a story, explain what information is being revealed: Investigators determined that Johnson wrote the document by analyzing its metadata, which indicated that it had been saved on his computer . Meta Platforms The company formerly known as Facebook, renamed in October 2021 to emphasize Mark Zuckerberg's new goal of building the metaverse . Meta is acceptable on first reference, but use the full name somewhere in the story. Describe it as the parent company of Facebook if the context isn't clear. The company also owns Instagram , a photo- and video-sharing service; the WhatsApp messaging service; and Messenger . Meta calls this collection of businesses Family of Apps . Its other business segment, Reality Labs , includes virtual and augmented reality hardware and software such as the Oculus VR headset. See Facebook (social platform) ; metaverse . metaverse A term minted by the science fiction writer Neal Stephenson in his 1992 novel "Snow Crash," now used to describe a proposed immersive version of the internet accessed via virtual reality headsets, augmented reality glasses, phone apps or other devices. Think of the metaverse as the internet brought to life, or at least rendered in 3D. Facebook co-founder Mark Zuckerberg has been a major metaverse proponent, even renaming Facebook the company to Meta Platforms in 2021, although Meta's early metaverse offerings have not proven popular. See Meta Platforms . Microsoft A software and internet services company historically best known for its Windows operating system and Office productivity software. Microsoft also runs one of the world's largest cloud computing operations under the name Azure and holds a major footprint in video games thanks to its Xbox family of gaming consoles. The company has also taken a significant step into artificial intelligence by incorporating an AI chatbot based on the GPT technology developed by OpenAI into its search engine, Bing . See the Artificial Intelligence chapter. microtargeting The practice of targeting ads to small groups of people, sometimes even individuals, based on data collected by advertisers and internet companies like Meta Platforms and Google. mips Acronym for million instructions per second . Spell out on first reference. mobile payment Typically refers to a payment for goods or services made by tapping a phone or smartwatch near a card reader at a physical retail store or business. A form of payment previously provided to a mobile payment service, usually a credit or debit card, gets charged. Not all card readers and businesses accept mobile payments, although the number is growing. Apple Pay and Google Pay are among the major services. Although these services are typically used for in-person payments, some also offer web and app payment options. Such services often use a substitute card number on the phone or watch to increase security. While a customer's regular card account gets charged for transactions, hackers who steal the substitute number cannot use it without also having the device present to verify the transaction. In a broader sense, mobile payments can also refer to sending money to friends or family through an app using a payment service such as Venmo . In some developing countries, where credit cards and bank accounts aren't as widespread, mobile payments can refer to the use of text messaging and other means to transfer money or buy goods and services. See digital wallet, mobile wallet . net neutrality The idea that internet service providers shouldn't favor or discriminate against some websites or services over others. Internet service providers such as phone and cable companies typically oppose net neutrality regulations. Office Software package made by Microsoft. The main components include Word for word processing, Excel for spreadsheets, PowerPoint for presentations, Outlook for email and OneNote for note-taking. The company has also extended Office to include such collaborative tools as SharePoint and Teams and the cloud-storage service OneDrive . Microsoft now prefers to sell Office via an online subscription called Office 365 . offline, online OpenAI An artificial intelligence company best known for developing ChatGPT and the AI large language models on which the chatbot is based. OpenAI started as a nonprofit in 2015 with a mission to advance AI in a way that benefits humanity. It later incorporated a for-profit arm and shifted most of its workforce to that business, but retained a nonprofit board of directors that governed the privately held company. OpenAI's unusual structure and shift from nonprofit to big business contributed to the temporary ouster of CEO Sam Altman in late 2023 and led a former financial backer and board member, Elon Musk, to sue the company in 2024. OpenAI has close ties to Microsoft, which has invested billions of dollars in the company and has rights to use its AI models. ChatGPT's products include its GPT language models and DALL-E image generator. See the Artificial Intelligence chapter. opt in, opt out (v.), opt-in, opt-out (adj.) Terms used to describe how a service obtains permission for collecting and sharing data. The opt-in option requires explicit permission, while the opt-out approach typically assumes permission unless someone takes a proactive step to withdraw consent. When writing about opt-in permission, specify how a service defines such permission whenever possible. For instance, a company with an opt-in approach may request users to accept a lengthy document that isn't prominent or easy to understand, which users are more likely to simply accept than to read through. Be mindful that while a company may promise to allow users to opt out of a practice, the consumer must know that the practice exists and how to opt out of it. See internet privacy . PC Acceptable on all references for personal computer . The term typically refers to traditional desktop and laptop computers, although it sometimes includes tablets with detachable keyboards. PDF Acceptable in all references for Portable Document Format . A file format that allows a document to be shared among multiple types of computers without losing its formatting. phishing A form of internet fraud that aims to steal personal information such as credit card numbers, Social Security numbers, user IDs and passwords. Photoshop Trademark for a brand of photo-editing software. Use the generic form if the brand is uncertain. Pinduoduo A Chinese e-commerce site that owns the Temu online shopping platform. Pinterest A service in which users collect and share images in theme-based collections, also known as pinboards or simply boards . Images that are shared on Pinterest — or pinned — are sometimes referred to as pins . Pinterest allows people to search for and pin images as inspiration for fashion, interior design, travel and more. record, recorded, recording Use record (or album or LP ) for the vinyl discs used to play back audio. Use recording and recorded for audio also available in other formats such as CDs and digital downloads . For example: I still have several Beatles records in the attic. Streaming services account for most of the recording industry's revenue for recorded music. Reddit A social network that features message board-style posts organized into topic-based pages called subreddits where users share and converse. "Ask me anything" posts give users an opportunity to pose questions to public figures, topic experts and people who have had interesting experiences. AMA is acceptable on second reference. robot, robotics A robot is a mechanical device that typically can move and perform actions on its own using motors, sensors and computing. Examples include robotic arms used in factories or autonomous wheeled vacuum cleaners. Some robots are mostly remote-controlled, such as those used in surgery. A humanoid is a robot that physically resembles a person, though it's still uncommon outside science fiction and research labs. Avoid calling something a robot if it is more like a remote-controlled puppet. Artificial intelligence software can be a component of a robot , but avoid calling something a robot or robotic if it is entirely software-based, such as automated systems used in online conversation or to help make decisions. However, the term bot can be used to describe such software-based systems. A chatbot is a bot that can engage in conversations with people. Robotics is the study and development of robots and similar machines such as drones and self-driving cars. See the Artificial Intelligence chapter. ROM Acronym for read-only memory , computer memory whose contents cannot be changed. ROM acceptable in all references. Samsung Electronics Maker of appliances, consumer electronics, semiconductor chips and other products. Samsung is acceptable on first reference in stories about consumer electronics, although it is one business of the Samsung conglomerate and needs to be distinguished in broader stories about the company, Samsung Electronics. Samsung is one of the world's leading maker of smartphones; its most popular models carry the brand name Galaxy . Samsung Electronics also makes television sets, refrigerators, washing machines and other consumer products. It also owns an audio and car technology business, Harman . scraping Copying online data or content, manually or using automated scraping tools, for use or display elsewhere. Depending on what's being scraped, this can raise intellectual property, security or privacy issues, though there are legitimate uses of the technique. search engine optimization Any of a number of methods, both human- and machine-powered, used to improve the prominence of online content in search engines, thus increasing traffic to the content. SEO is acceptable on second reference. selfie A self-portrait photo generally taken with a camera-equipped phone or webcam. Signal Secure messaging service offering end-to-end encryption . That improves message security, although the service requires users to sign up with their real phone numbers. See internet security . Sina Weibo Chinese social networking service focused on short messages, similar to X. Skype A service, owned by Microsoft, that allows users to communicate by voice, video and instant message over the internet. Skype is used informally as a verb for using the service, particularly when communicating on video. Slack A workplace chat service used to exchange messages and files. Often used instead of email in some settings. Do not use as a verb unless in a direct quotation, in which case it needs explanation. "She Slacked me about the upcoming meeting," he said, referring to a message sent via the workplace chat service. smart devices General term for a category of electronic gadgets that typically connect to the internet and offer advanced features. In general, use two words except for smartphone and smartwatch . Many such devices are also referred to as connected , as in connected cars or connected TVs , though internet-connected is preferred. While manufacturers have been promoting the conveniences of having smart devices such as refrigerators and door locks, such devices also carry security and privacy risks. Hackers, for instance, might be able to access mics and cameras on some devices to spy on their owners. They also might be able to unlock doors remotely, although it may also be easier for an intruder to break a window. And some companies collect data on usage that can be used to piece together when someone is home or how often the person has exercised. Such data can also be sought in police investigations and lawsuits. SMS An abbreviation for Short Message Service . Text messaging is preferred. Snapchat A service that lets users capture and share photos or video clips, often with text, drawings or other adornments. Popular among younger people, it is best known for messages that automatically disappear a few seconds after viewing. Use lowercase snap for a Snapchat posting social media An umbrella term for online services that people use to share posts, photos and videos with small or large groups of people, privately or publicly. Established services include Facebook, X, TikTok, Snapchat and Instagram . Others, such as China's Sina Weibo , are popular regionally. While enormously popular, social media can also expose users to privacy risks, harassment, and polarizing misinformation. Messaging services such as WhatsApp and Signal are often lumped with social media but are not technically social media services. But the line has blurred in recent years, as chat services such as Apple's iMessage, WeChat from the Chinese company Tencent and the Japan-based Line take on broader functions such as payments and group sharing. Use caution comparing usage figures reported by social networks; many companies use different ways to calculate "active users." story (on a social platform) A slideshow featuring a series of photos and/or videos that users of various social and messaging platforms — most notably Instagram, Snapchat and Facebook — can post to their accounts. The images are often adorned with text, digital scribbles or graphical elements. They typically disappear after 24 hours, though some platforms archive them for future sharing. Tencent Chinese technology company known for the messaging service WeChat , called Weixin in China. It also owns another messaging service, QQ , along with other digital services such as video games and music and video subscriptions. text, texting, texted Acceptable in all usages as a verb for to send a text message . TikTok Video service popular with teens and young adults. Many of the short videos are set to music and are distinguished by their lighthearted style. Parent company is Chinese tech giant ByteDance, which also has a similar app for Chinese users, called Douyin . In 2020, the Trump administration tried to force a sale of TikTok to U.S. companies on national security grounds. That year, the administration also brokered a deal that would have had Oracle and Walmart take a large stake in the app and partner with TikTok to form a new U.S. company. The Biden administration revoked an effort by the Trump administration intended to ban the popular app, but then issued an executive order taking aim at protecting Americans' sensitive personal data from foreign adversaries, including China. trending (v. or adj.) Used to indicate that a particular topic, word, phrase or piece of content is getting a lot of attention on a social network, search engine or website. Do not use without context and explanation, including describing the location of users where the topic is trending. The Oscars are trending worldwide on Instagram today. unfollow To remove an account from the list of accounts that populate one's feed on a social network. unfriend To remove someone from a list of friends that one is connected to, usually on Facebook. URL Acceptable in all references for uniform resource locator , an internet address. USB Acceptable in all references for Universal Serial Bus , used to designate a standard interface for connecting peripherals to a computer. When the type of USB needs to be noted, use a hyphen: USB-C . user interface The features of a device, program or website that enable control by a user. UI is acceptable on second reference. It is a key element of user experience , or UX , which is a broader term referring to how people experience a given product or service. virtual private network A service that shields internet users by encrypting their data traffic, preventing others from observing their online activities. Organizations use VPNs for secure communications over the public internet. Individuals can also use VPN services to mask their location in order to circumvent censorship or geography-based online viewing restrictions. VPN is acceptable on second reference. virtual reality, augmented reality Virtual reality is a computer-generated simulation of an interactive three-dimensional environment. Virtual reality experiences typically require the use of headsets, hand-held controllers and other electronic equipment that allow a person to interact with the simulation. A similar concept, augmented reality , involves the projection of interactive computer-generated images into a person's real-world surroundings. VR and AR are acceptable on second reference. virus, worm A computer virus is any malicious, invasive program designed to infect and disrupt computers. A worm s a type of virus that spreads on networks such as the internet, copying itself from one computer to another without human intervention. web Short form of World Wide Web , a part of the internet that enables the distribution of image-rich content and information. The web is not the same as the internet , but is a subset of that network of networks. Other applications such as email exist on the internet. When referring to websites In stories, generally use the name of the website or service rather than the web address. It's Facebook , not Facebook.com . Also, website, webcam, webcast, webfeed, webmaster, webpage . But web address, web browser . See internet . web browser Software for viewing and interacting with websites on a computer or another device. WeChat Messaging service owned by Chinese tech giant Tencent . Popular mostly in mainland China and known as Weixin in Chinese. Notable for combining functions and services that are traditionally separated elsewhere. WeChat offers basic chat features such as instant messaging and calling, and hosts group chats where users can discuss topics like sports, technology, social issues, investments and celebrities. WeChat also lets people pay for movies, food delivery, public transit and utility bills; split restaurant checks with friends; and make other payments. WeChat lacks end-to-end encryption such as that found in Signal , Meta Platform's WhatsApp , Facebook and Messenger , and Apple's iMessage . Chinese dissidents and activists have long suspected that authorities are able to monitor what they have been saying on the services. The company has denied keeping a record of user chats. WhatsApp Messaging service owned by Meta Platforms. widget In a technology context, a small module with a specific purpose that appears on a website, desktop or other interface and allows access to content or functions. Wi-Fi A wireless communications technology often used to connect to home and business networks, which in turn connect to the internet. Wi-Fi has a shorter range than cellular technology but is convenient for sharing one internet connection among multiple devices. A Wi-Fi connection is sometimes called a hot spot . wiki Software that allows a group of users to add, delete, edit and share information on a website. wireless A set of technologies for delivering data without wires. Common types include: cellular Access comes through a phone company, such as Verizon or AT&T. Signals can travel far, offering broad coverage, but many phone plans offer a limited amount of data before charging extra and/or slowing speeds. Wi-Fi Access comes through a residential or business broadband provider, such as Comcast. The coverage range is shorter, but home plans typically offer unlimited data. Although Wi-Fi is a wireless technology, it often connects to a home or business network that requires wires. Bluetooth A short-range wireless technology for connecting devices directly to each other, such as a smartwatch to a phone. NFC , or Near-Field Communication A wireless technology that lets two devices nearby, such as phones or sensors, communicate with each other. Its best-known use is for mobile payments , in which placing a phone near a payment reader at a store triggers the payment. NFC is acceptable in all references, but explain it. Specify the type of wireless technology when that is pertinent to a story. X A social network, formerly called Twitter , on which users share text, photos, video and links with their followers in short messages. Twitter existed from 2006 until 2023. Elon Musk purchased Twitter in October 2022 for $44 billion. In July 2023, Musk renamed Twitter as X. Use the social platform X on first reference. Reference to its former name of Twitter may or may not be necessary, depending on the story. Limit use of the verbs tweet and tweeted other than in direct quotations. Instead: posted on X, said in a post on X , etc. Though its cultural relevance has declined, X is still used by influential people, including journalists, policymakers and celebrities. It is not necessarily reflective of the general population. It should not be a substitute for traditional interviews and reporting. Xiaomi A Chinese company known for its value-for-money smartphones and smart devices.  The company was briefly added to a U.S. Defense Department blacklist in January 2021, in the last few days of the Trump administration, which accused it of links to China's military. It was removed from the list later that spring. XML Abbreviation for Extensible Markup Language , a structured way to encode documents containing text, data, graphics, video and more in formats that can be read by both humans and machines. Such documents can be stored, transmitted and reformatted at will. Yahoo An online services provider. Do not use the exclamation point in its formal name. YouTube Video-sharing service owned by Google. It has helped promote videos ranging from educational to whimsical and made celebrities out of ordinary people. The company has faced backlash over what some consider hate speech or harassment in videos. The service made several policy changes to attempt to cut down on harassment and threats, though questionable videos still slip through. Separately, Google and YouTube agreed in 2019 to pay $170 million to settle allegations in the U.S. that the video service failed to screen out children from using its service, thus violating a federal law that restricts data collection on children under 13. entry_header: balance of payments, balance of trade
text_content: The balance of payments is the difference between the amount of money that leaves a nation and the amount that enters it during a period of time. The balance of payments is determined by computing the amount of money a nation and its citizens send abroad for all purposes – including goods and services purchased, travel, loans, foreign aid, etc. – and subtracting from it the amount that foreign nations send into the nation for similar purposes. The balance of trade is the difference between the monetary value of the goods a nation imports and the goods it exports. An example illustrating the difference between the two: The United States and its citizens might send $10 billion abroad – $5 billion for goods, $3 billion for loans and foreign aid, $1 billion for services and $1 billion for tourism and other purposes. Other nations might send $9 billion into the United States – $6 billion for U.S. goods, $2 billion for services and $1 billion for tourism and other purposes. The United States would have a balance-of-payments deficit of $1 billion but a balance-of-trade surplus of $1 billion.
